Description: Lower body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; white slip; interior glazed black; undetermined interior decoration in added white and added red; below, two white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of female figure to right (only bottom of garment and feet in outline remaining); below, two bands; below from left, tongue pattern around handle root (now missing); part of guilloche pattern in handle zone above brown band.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the Aphaia Group. The painter and the group are named after the chalice found in the sanctuary of Aphaia on Aegina and vessels from this group display a thematic unity. All the vessels describe figures in garments and in particular, the lower parts of chitons and himatia. None of the vessels in this group have any filling ornament and the interior decoration of some of the vessels consists of komasts rendered in the light on dark technique. The number '90' is written in pencil on the interior.
Bibliographic references: CVA Philadelphia II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Fasc. 29, The University Museum Philadelphia II (p. 15, no. E175.A1, pl. 5, Ia)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 111, 281, no. 785, pl. 102)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0854) (phase 2)
